examples.description: Chaes has collected system information, including the machine name and OS version.

examples.name: CharmPower
examples.description: CharmPower can enumerate the OS version and computer name on a targeted system.

examples.name: ChChes
examples.description: ChChes collects the victim hostname, window resolution, and Microsoft Windows version.

examples.name: Chimera
examples.description: Chimera has used fsutil fsinfo drives, systeminfo, and vssadmin list shadows for system information including shadow volumes and drive information.

examples.name: Chrommme
examples.description: Chrommme has the ability to list drives and obtain the computer name of a compromised host.

examples.name: Clambling
examples.description: Clambling can discover the hostname, computer name, and Windows version of a targeted machine.

examples.name: cmd
examples.description: cmd can be used to find information about the operating system.

examples.name: Comnie
examples.description: Comnie collects the hostname of the victim machine.

examples.name: Confucius
examples.description: Confucius has used a file stealer that can examine system drives, including those other than the C drive.

examples.name: CORESHELL
examples.description: CORESHELL collects hostname, volume serial number and OS version data from the victim and sends the information to its C2 server.

examples.name: CozyCar
examples.description: A system info module in CozyCar gathers information on the victim host’s configuration.

examples.name: CrackMapExec
examples.description: CrackMapExec can enumerate the system drives and associated system name.

examples.name: Crimson
examples.description: Crimson contains a command to collect the victim PC name, disk drive information, and operating system.

examples.name: Cuba
examples.description: Cuba can enumerate local drives, disk type, and disk free space.

examples.name: Cyclops Blink
examples.description: Cyclops Blink has the ability to query device information.

examples.name: DarkComet
examples.description: DarkComet can collect the computer name, RAM used, and operating system version from the victim’s machine.

examples.name: Darkhotel
examples.description: Darkhotel has collected the hostname, OS version, service pack version, and the processor architecture from the victim’s machine.

examples.name: DarkTortilla
examples.description: DarkTortilla can obtain system information by querying the Win32_ComputerSystem, Win32_BIOS, Win32_MotherboardDevice, Win32_PnPEntity, and Win32_DiskDrive WMI objects.

examples.name: DarkWatchman
examples.description: DarkWatchman can collect the OS version, system architecture, uptime, and computer name.

examples.name: DEADEYE
examples.description: DEADEYE can enumerate a victim computer's volume serial number and host name.

examples.name: DEATHRANSOM
examples.description: DEATHRANSOM can enumerate logical drives on a target system.

examples.name: Denis
examples.description: Denis collects OS information and the computer name from the victim’s machine.

examples.name: Derusbi
examples.description: Derusbi gathers the name of the local host, version of GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), and the system information about the CPU, machine, and operating system.

examples.name: Diavol
examples.description: Diavol can collect the computer name and OS version from the system.

examples.name: down_new
examples.description: down_new has the ability to identify the system volume information of a compromised host.

examples.name: DownPaper
examples.description: DownPaper collects the victim host name and serial number, and then sends the information to the C2 server.

examples.name: Dridex
examples.description: Dridex has collected the computer name and OS architecture information from the system.

examples.name: DropBook
examples.description: DropBook has checked for the presence of Arabic language in the infected machine's settings.

examples.name: dsquery
examples.description: dsquery has the ability to enumerate various information, such as the operating system and host name, for systems within a domain.

examples.name: Dtrack
examples.description: Dtrack can collect the victim's computer name, hostname and adapter information to create a unique identifier.

examples.name: DustySky
examples.description: DustySky extracts basic information about the operating system.

examples.name: Dyre
examples.description: Dyre has the ability to identify the computer name, OS version, and hardware configuration on a compromised host.

examples.name: Egregor
examples.description: Egregor can perform a language check of the infected system and can query the CPU information (cupid).

examples.name: Elise
examples.description: Elise executes systeminfo after initial communication is made to the remote server.

examples.name: Emissary
examples.description: Emissary has the capability to execute ver and systeminfo commands.

examples.name: Empire
examples.description: Empire can enumerate host system information like OS, architecture, domain name, applied patches, and more.

examples.name: EnvyScout
examples.description: EnvyScout can determine whether the ISO payload was received by a Windows or iOS device.

examples.name: Epic
examples.description: Epic collects the OS version, hardware information, computer name, available system memory status, disk space information, and system and user language settings.

examples.name: EVILNUM
examples.description: EVILNUM can obtain the computer name from the victim's system.

examples.name: Explosive
examples.description: Explosive has collected the computer name from the infected host.

examples.name: FALLCHILL
examples.description: FALLCHILL can collect operating system (OS) version information, processor information, system name, and information about installed disks from the victim.

examples.name: FatDuke
examples.description: FatDuke can collect the user name, Windows version, computer name, and available space on discs from a compromised host.

examples.name: Felismus
examples.description: Felismus collects the system information, including hostname and OS version, and sends it to the C2 server.

examples.name: FELIXROOT
examples.description: FELIXROOT collects the victim’s computer name, processor architecture, OS version, volume serial number, and system type.

examples.name: Ferocious
examples.description: Ferocious can use GET.WORKSPACE in Microsoft Excel to determine the OS version of the compromised host.

examples.name: FIN13
examples.description: FIN13 has collected local host information by utilizing Windows commands systeminfo, fsutil, and fsinfo. FIN13 has also utilized a compromised Symantex Altiris console and LanDesk account to retrieve host information.

examples.name: FIN8
examples.description: FIN8 has used PowerShell Scripts to check the architecture of a compromised machine before the selection of a 32-bit or 64-bit version of a malicious .NET loader.

examples.name: Final1stspy
examples.description: Final1stspy obtains victim Microsoft Windows version information and CPU architecture.

examples.name: FinFisher
examples.description: FinFisher checks if the victim OS is 32 or 64-bit.

examples.name: FlawedAmmyy
examples.description: FlawedAmmyy can collect the victim's operating system and computer name during the initial infection.

examples.name: Frankenstein
examples.description: During Frankenstein, the threat actors used Empire to obtain the compromised machine's name.

examples.name: FunnyDream
examples.description: FunnyDream can enumerate all logical drives on a targeted machine.

examples.name: FunnyDream
examples.description: During FunnyDream, the threat actors used Systeminfo to collect information on targeted hosts.

examples.name: Fysbis
examples.description: Fysbis has used the command ls /etc | egrep -e"fedora*|debian*|gentoo*|mandriva*|mandrake*|meego*|redhat*|lsb-*|sun-*|SUSE*|release" to determine which Linux OS version is running.

examples.name: Gamaredon Group
examples.description: A Gamaredon Group file stealer can gather the victim's computer name and drive serial numbers to send to a C2 server.

examples.name: Gelsemium
examples.description: Gelsemium can determine the operating system and whether a targeted machine has a 32 or 64 bit architecture.

examples.name: Get2
examples.description: Get2 has the ability to identify the computer name and Windows version of an infected host.

examples.name: gh0st RAT
examples.description: gh0st RAT has gathered system architecture, processor, OS configuration, and installed hardware information.

examples.name: Gold Dragon
examples.description: Gold Dragon collects endpoint information using the systeminfo command.

examples.name: GoldenSpy
examples.description: GoldenSpy has gathered operating system information.

examples.name: Grandoreiro
examples.description: Grandoreiro can collect the computer name and OS version from a compromised host.

examples.name: GravityRAT
examples.description: GravityRAT collects the MAC address, computer name, and CPU information.

examples.name: Green Lambert
examples.description: Green Lambert can use uname to identify the operating system name, version, and processor type.

examples.name: GRIFFON
examples.description: GRIFFON has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve information about a victim's computer, including the resolution of the workstation .

examples.name: GrimAgent
examples.description: GrimAgent can collect the OS, and build version on a compromised host.

examples.name: HALFBAKED
examples.description: HALFBAKED can obtain information about the OS, processor, and BIOS.

examples.name: HAPPYWORK
examples.description: can collect system information, including computer name, system manufacturer, IsDebuggerPresent state, and execution path.

examples.name: HAWKBALL
examples.description: HAWKBALL can collect the OS version, architecture information, and computer name.

examples.name: HELLOKITTY
examples.description: HELLOKITTY can enumerate logical drives on a target system.

examples.name: HermeticWiper
examples.description: HermeticWiper can determine the OS version, bitness, and enumerate physical drives on a targeted host.

examples.name: HEXANE
examples.description: HEXANE has collected the hostname of a compromised machine.

examples.name: Heyoka Backdoor
examples.description: Heyoka Backdoor can enumerate drives on a compromised host.

examples.name: Higaisa
examples.description: Higaisa collected the system volume serial number, GUID, and computer name.

examples.name: Hildegard
examples.description: Hildegard has collected the host's OS, CPU, and memory information.

examples.name: HOPLIGHT
examples.description: HOPLIGHT has been observed collecting victim machine information like OS version, volume information, and more.

examples.name: HotCroissant
examples.description: HotCroissant has the ability to determine if the current user is an administrator, Windows product name, processor name, screen resolution, and physical RAM of the infected host.

examples.name: Hydraq
examples.description: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as computer name, OS version, processor speed, memory size, and CPU speed.

examples.name: IceApple
examples.description: The IceApple Server Variable Dumper module iterates over all server variables present for the current request and returns them to the adversary.

examples.name: IcedID
examples.description: IcedID has the ability to identify the computer name and OS version on a compromised host.

examples.name: Inception
examples.description: Inception has used a reconnaissance module to gather information about the operating system and hardware on the infected host.

examples.name: Industroyer
examples.description: Industroyer collects the victim machine’s Windows GUID.

examples.name: InnaputRAT
examples.description: InnaputRAT gathers volume drive information and system information.

examples.name: InvisiMole
examples.description: InvisiMole can gather information on the mapped drives, OS version, computer name, DEP policy, memory size, and system volume serial number.

examples.name: Ixeshe
examples.description: Ixeshe collects the computer name of the victim's system during the initial infection.

examples.name: JHUHUGIT
examples.description: JHUHUGIT obtains a build identifier as well as victim hard drive information from Windows registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Disk\Enum. Another JHUHUGIT variant gathers the victim storage volume serial number and the storage device name.

examples.name: JPIN
examples.description: JPIN can obtain system information such as OS version and disk space.

examples.name: jRAT
examples.description: jRAT collects information about the OS (version, build type, install date) as well as system up-time upon receiving a connection from a backdoor.

examples.name: KARAE
examples.description: KARAE can collect system information.

examples.name: Kasidet
examples.description: Kasidet has the ability to obtain a victim's system name and operating system version.

examples.name: Kazuar
examples.description: Kazuar gathers information on the system and local drives.

examples.name: Ke3chang
examples.description: Ke3chang performs operating system information discovery using systeminfo and has used implants to identify the system language and computer name.

examples.name: Kerrdown
examples.description: Kerrdown has the ability to determine if the compromised host is running a 32 or 64 bit OS architecture.

examples.name: Kessel
examples.description: Kessel has collected the system architecture, OS version, and MAC address information.

examples.name: Kevin
examples.description: Kevin can enumerate the OS version and hostname of a targeted machine.

examples.name: KeyBoy
examples.description: KeyBoy can gather extended system information, such as information about the operating system, disks, and memory.

examples.name: KEYMARBLE
examples.description: KEYMARBLE has the capability to collect the computer name, language settings, the OS version, CPU information, disk devices, and time elapsed since system start.

examples.name: KGH_SPY
examples.description: KGH_SPY can collect drive information from a compromised host.

examples.name: KillDisk
examples.description: KillDisk retrieves the hard disk name by calling the CreateFileA to \.\PHYSICALDRIVE0 API.

examples.name: Kimsuky
examples.description: Kimsuky has enumerated drives, OS type, OS version, and other information using a script or the "systeminfo" command.

examples.name: Koadic
examples.description: Koadic can obtain the OS version and build, computer name, and processor architecture from a compromised host.

examples.name: Kobalos
examples.description: Kobalos can record the hostname and kernel version of the target machine.

examples.name: KOCTOPUS
examples.description: KOCTOPUS has checked the OS version using wmic.exe and the find command.

examples.name: KOMPROGO
examples.description: KOMPROGO is capable of retrieving information about the infected system.

examples.name: KONNI
examples.description: KONNI can gather the OS version, architecture information, connected drives, hostname, RAM size, and disk space information from the victim’s machine and has used cmd /c systeminfo command to get a snapshot of the current system state of the target machine.

examples.name: KOPILUWAK
examples.description: KOPILUWAK can discover logical drive information on compromised hosts.

examples.name: Kwampirs
examples.description: Kwampirs collects OS version information such as registered owner details, manufacturer details, processor type, available storage, installed patches, hostname, version info, system date, and other system information by using the commands systeminfo, net config workstation, hostname, ver, set, and date /t.

examples.name: Lazarus Group

examples.name: LightNeuron
examples.description: LightNeuron gathers the victim computer name using the Win32 API call GetComputerName.

examples.name: Linfo
examples.description: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information.

examples.name: LiteDuke
examples.description: LiteDuke can enumerate the CPUID and BIOS version on a compromised system.

examples.name: LitePower
examples.description: LitePower has the ability to list local drives and enumerate the OS architecture.

examples.name: Lizar
examples.description: Lizar can collect the computer name from the machine,.

examples.name: Lokibot
examples.description: Lokibot has the ability to discover the computer name and Windows product name/version.

examples.name: LoudMiner
examples.description: LoudMiner has monitored CPU usage.

examples.name: Lucifer
examples.description: Lucifer can collect the computer name, system architecture, default language, and processor frequency of a compromised host.

examples.name: Machete
examples.description: Machete collects the hostname of the target computer.

examples.name: MacMa
examples.description: MacMa can collect information about a compromised computer, including: Hardware UUID, Mac serial number, macOS version, and disk sizes.

examples.name: macOS.OSAMiner
examples.description: macOS.OSAMiner can gather the device serial number and has checked to ensure there is enough disk space using the Unix utility df.

examples.name: Mafalda
examples.description: Mafalda can collect the computer name and enumerate all drives on a compromised host.

examples.name: Magic Hound
examples.description: Magic Hound malware has used a PowerShell command to check the victim system architecture to determine if it is an x64 machine. Other malware has obtained the OS version, UUID, and computer/host name to send to the C2 server.

examples.name: MarkiRAT
examples.description: MarkiRAT can obtain the computer name from a compromised host.

examples.name: Maze
examples.description: Maze has checked the language of the infected system using the "GetUSerDefaultUILanguage" function.

examples.name: metaMain
examples.description: metaMain can collect the computer name from a compromised host.

examples.name: Metamorfo
examples.description: Metamorfo has collected the hostname and operating system version from the compromised host.

examples.name: Meteor
examples.description: Meteor has the ability to discover the hostname of a compromised host.

examples.name: Micropsia
examples.description: Micropsia gathers the hostname and OS version from the victim’s machine.

examples.name: Milan
examples.description: Milan can enumerate the targeted machine's name and GUID.

examples.name: MiniDuke
examples.description: MiniDuke can gather the hostname on a compromised machine.

examples.name: MirageFox
examples.description: MirageFox can collect CPU and architecture information from the victim’s machine.

examples.name: Mis-Type
examples.description: The initial beacon packet for Mis-Type contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.

examples.name: Misdat
examples.description: The initial beacon packet for Misdat contains the operating system version of the victim.

examples.name: MobileOrder
examples.description: MobileOrder has a command to upload to its C2 server victim mobile device information, including IMEI, IMSI, SIM card serial number, phone number, Android version, and other information.

examples.name: MoleNet
examples.description: MoleNet can collect information about the about the system.

examples.name: Mongall
examples.description: Mongall can identify drives on compromised hosts and retrieve the hostname via gethostbyname.

examples.name: MoonWind
examples.description: MoonWind can obtain the victim hostname, Windows version, RAM amount, number of drives, and screen resolution.

examples.name: More_eggs
examples.description: More_eggs has the capability to gather the OS version and computer name.

examples.name: Moses Staff
examples.description: Moses Staff collected information about the infected host, including the machine names and OS architecture.

examples.name: MuddyWater
examples.description: MuddyWater has used malware that can collect the victim’s OS version and machine name.

examples.name: MURKYTOP
examples.description: MURKYTOP has the capability to retrieve information about the OS.

examples.name: Mustang Panda
examples.description: Mustang Panda has gathered system information using systeminfo.

examples.name: Naid
examples.description: Naid collects a unique identifier (UID) from a compromised host.

examples.name: NanHaiShu
examples.description: NanHaiShu can gather the victim computer name and serial number.

examples.name: NavRAT
examples.description: NavRAT uses systeminfo on a victim’s machine.

examples.name: NDiskMonitor
examples.description: NDiskMonitor obtains the victim computer name and encrypts the information to send over its C2 channel.

examples.name: Nebulae
examples.description: Nebulae can discover logical drive information including the drive type, free space, and volume information.

examples.name: Neoichor
examples.description: Neoichor can collect the OS version and computer name from a compromised host.

examples.name: Netwalker
examples.description: Netwalker can determine the system architecture it is running on to choose which version of the DLL to use.

examples.name: NETWIRE
examples.description: NETWIRE can discover and collect victim system information.

examples.name: njRAT
examples.description: njRAT enumerates the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.

examples.name: NOKKI
examples.description: NOKKI can gather information on drives and the operating system on the victim’s machine.

examples.name: ObliqueRAT
examples.description: ObliqueRAT has the ability to check for blocklisted computer names on infected endpoints.

examples.name: OceanSalt
examples.description: OceanSalt can collect the computer name from the system.

examples.name: Octopus
examples.description: Octopus can collect system drive information, the computer name, the size of the disk, OS version, and OS architecture information.

examples.name: OilRig
examples.description: OilRig has run hostname and systeminfo on a victim.

examples.name: Okrum
examples.description: Okrum can collect computer name, locale information, and information about the OS and architecture.

examples.name: OopsIE
examples.description: OopsIE checks for information on the CPU fan, temperature, mouse, hard disk, and motherboard as part of its anti-VM checks.

examples.name: Operation CuckooBees
examples.description: During Operation CuckooBees, the threat actors used the systeminfo command to gather details about a compromised system.

examples.name: Operation Honeybee
examples.description: During Operation Honeybee, the threat actors collected the computer name, OS, and other system information using cmd /c systeminfo > %temp%\ temp.ini.

examples.name: Operation Wocao
examples.description: During Operation Wocao, threat actors discovered the local disks attached to the system and their hardware information including manufacturer and model, as well as the OS versions of systems connected to a targeted network.

examples.name: Orz
examples.description: Orz can gather the victim OS version and whether it is 64 or 32 bit.

examples.name: OSInfo
examples.description: OSInfo discovers information about the infected machine.

examples.name: OSX/Shlayer
examples.description: OSX/Shlayer has collected the IOPlatformUUID, session UID, and the OS version using the command sw_vers -productVersion.

examples.name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
examples.description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D collects processor information, memory information, computer name, hardware UUID, serial number, and operating system version. OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D has used the ioreg command to gather some of this information.

examples.name: Pasam
examples.description: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as hostname and free disk space.

examples.name: Patchwork
examples.description: Patchwork collected the victim computer name, OS version, and architecture type and sent the information to its C2 server. Patchwork also enumerated all available drives on the victim's machine.

examples.name: Pay2Key
examples.description: Pay2Key has the ability to gather the hostname of the victim machine.

examples.name: Penquin
examples.description: Penquin can report the file system type and disk space of a compromised host to C2.

examples.name: PinchDuke
examples.description: PinchDuke gathers system configuration information.

examples.name: PingPull
examples.description: PingPull can retrieve the hostname of a compromised host.

examples.name: PipeMon
examples.description: PipeMon can collect and send OS version and computer name as a part of its C2 beacon.

examples.name: Pisloader
examples.description: Pisloader has a command to collect victim system information, including the system name and OS version.

examples.name: PLAINTEE
examples.description: PLAINTEE collects general system enumeration data about the infected machine and checks the OS version.

examples.name: PoetRAT
examples.description: PoetRAT has the ability to gather information about the compromised host.

examples.name: Pony
examples.description: Pony has collected the Service Pack, language, and region information to send to the C2.

examples.name: POORAIM
examples.description: POORAIM can identify system information, including battery status.

examples.name: PoshC2
examples.description: PoshC2 contains modules, such as Get-ComputerInfo, for enumerating common system information.

examples.name: PowerDuke
examples.description: PowerDuke has commands to get information about the victim's name, build, version, serial number, and memory usage.

examples.name: PowerShower
examples.description: PowerShower has collected system information on the infected host.

examples.name: POWERSTATS
examples.description: POWERSTATS can retrieve OS name/architecture and computer/domain name information from compromised hosts.

examples.name: POWRUNER
examples.description: POWRUNER may collect information about the system by running hostname and systeminfo on a victim.

examples.name: Prikormka
examples.description: A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about Windows OS version, computer name, battery info, and physical memory.

examples.name: Proxysvc
examples.description: Proxysvc collects the OS version, country name, MAC address, computer name, physical memory statistics, and volume information for all drives on the system.

examples.name: PUNCHBUGGY
examples.description: PUNCHBUGGY can gather system information such as computer names.

examples.name: Pupy
examples.description: Pupy can grab a system’s information including the OS version, architecture, etc.

examples.name: QakBot
examples.description: QakBot can collect system information including the OS version and domain on a compromised host.

examples.name: QuasarRAT
examples.description: QuasarRAT can gather system information from the victim’s machine including the OS type.

examples.name: Ramsay
examples.description: Ramsay can detect system information--including disk names, total space, and remaining space--to create a hardware profile GUID which acts as a system identifier for operators.

examples.name: RATANKBA
examples.description: RATANKBA gathers information about the OS architecture, OS name, and OS version/Service pack.

examples.name: RCSession
examples.description: RCSession can gather system information from a compromised host.

examples.name: Reaver
examples.description: Reaver collects system information from the victim, including CPU speed, computer name, volume serial number, ANSI code page, OEM code page identifier for the OS, Microsoft Windows version, and memory information.

examples.name: RedLeaves
examples.description: RedLeaves can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.

examples.name: Remsec
examples.description: Remsec can obtain the OS version information, computer name, processor architecture, machine role, and OS edition.

examples.name: Revenge RAT
examples.description: Revenge RAT collects the CPU information, OS information, and system language.

examples.name: REvil
examples.description: REvil can identify the username, machine name, system language, keyboard layout, OS version, and system drive information on a compromised host.

examples.name: Rifdoor
examples.description: Rifdoor has the ability to identify the Windows version on the compromised host.

examples.name: Rising Sun
examples.description: Rising Sun can detect the computer name, operating system, and drive information, including drive type, total number of bytes on disk, total number of free bytes on disk, and name of a specified volume.

examples.name: Rocke
examples.description: Rocke has used uname -m to collect the name and information about the infected system's kernel.

examples.name: RogueRobin
examples.description: RogueRobin gathers BIOS versions and manufacturers, the number of CPU cores, the total physical memory, and the computer name.

examples.name: ROKRAT
examples.description: ROKRAT can gather the hostname and the OS version to ensure it doesn’t run on a Windows XP or Windows Server 2003 systems.

examples.name: RotaJakiro
examples.description: RotaJakiro executes a set of commands to collect device information, including uname.  Another example is the cat /etc/*release | uniq command used to collect the current OS distribution.

examples.name: Royal
examples.description: Royal can use GetNativeSystemInfo and GetLogicalDrives to enumerate system processors and logical drives.

examples.name: RTM
examples.description: RTM can obtain the computer name, OS version, and default language identifier.

examples.name: RunningRAT
examples.description: RunningRAT gathers the OS version, logical drives information, processor information, and volume information.

examples.name: Ryuk
examples.description: Ryuk has called GetLogicalDrives to emumerate all mounted drives, and GetDriveTypeW to determine the drive type.

examples.name: S-Type
examples.description: The initial beacon packet for S-Type contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.

examples.name: Saint Bot
examples.description: Saint Bot can identify the OS version, CPU, and other details from a victim's machine.

examples.name: Sandworm Team
examples.description: Sandworm Team used a backdoor to enumerate information about the infected system's operating system.

examples.name: Sardonic
examples.description: Sardonic has the ability to collect the computer name, CPU manufacturer name, and C:\ drive serial number from a compromised machine. Sardonic also has the ability to execute the ver and systeminfo commands.

examples.name: SDBbot
examples.description: SDBbot has the ability to identify the OS version, OS bit information and computer name.

examples.name: ServHelper
examples.description: ServHelper will attempt to enumerate Windows version and system architecture.

examples.name: ShadowPad
examples.description: ShadowPad has discovered system information including memory status, CPU frequency, OS versions, and volume serial numbers.

examples.name: Shamoon
examples.description: Shamoon obtains the victim's operating system version and keyboard layout and sends the information to the C2 server.

examples.name: Shark
examples.description: Shark can collect the GUID of a targeted machine.

examples.name: SharpDisco
examples.description: SharpDisco can use a plugin to enumerate system drives.

examples.name: SharpStage
examples.description: SharpStage has checked the system settings to see if Arabic is the configured language.

examples.name: SHARPSTATS
examples.description: SHARPSTATS has the ability to identify the IP address, machine name, and OS of the compromised host.

examples.name: ShimRatReporter
examples.description: ShimRatReporter gathered the operating system name and specific Windows version of an infected machine.

examples.name: SHUTTERSPEED
examples.description: SHUTTERSPEED can collect system information.

examples.name: SideCopy
examples.description: SideCopy has identified the OS version of a compromised host.

examples.name: SideTwist
examples.description: SideTwist can collect the computer name of a targeted system.

examples.name: Sidewinder
examples.description: Sidewinder has used tools to collect the computer name, OS version, installed hotfixes, as well as information regarding the memory and processor on a compromised host.

examples.name: SILENTTRINITY
examples.description: SILENTTRINITY can collect information related to a compromised host, including OS version and a list of drives.

examples.name: Skidmap

techniques.name: System Location Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may gather information in an attempt to calculate the geographical location of a victim host. Adversaries may use the information from System Location Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may gather information in an attempt to calculate the geographical location of a victim host. Adversaries may use the information from System Location Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.
Adversaries may attempt to infer the location of a system using various system checks, such as time zone, keyboard layout, and/or language settings. Windows API functions such as GetLocaleInfoW can also be used to determine the locale of the host. In cloud environments, an instance's availability zone may also be discovered by accessing the instance metadata service from the instance.
Adversaries may also attempt to infer the location of a victim host using IP addressing, such as via online geolocation IP-lookup services.

sub_techniques.name: System Language Discovery
sub_techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to gather information about the system language of a victim in order to infer the geographical location of that host. This information may be used to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether the adversary infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This decision may be employed by malware developers and operators to reduce their risk of attracting the attention of specific law enforcement agencies or prosecution/scrutiny from other entities.
sub_techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may attempt to gather information about the system language of a victim in order to infer the geographical location of that host. This information may be used to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether the adversary infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This decision may be employed by malware developers and operators to reduce their risk of attracting the attention of specific law enforcement agencies or prosecution/scrutiny from other entities.
There are various sources of data an adversary could use to infer system language, such as system defaults and keyboard layouts. Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary, but may involve behaviors such as Query Registry and calls to Native API functions.
For example, on a Windows system adversaries may attempt to infer the language of a system by querying the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Nls\Language or parsing the outputs of Windows API functions GetUserDefaultUILanguage, GetSystemDefaultUILanguage, GetKeyboardLayoutList and GetUserDefaultLangID.
On a macOS or Linux system, adversaries may query locale to retrieve the value of the $LANG environment variable.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may look for details about the network configuration and settings, such as IP and/or MAC addresses, of systems they access or through information discovery of remote systems. Several operating system administration utilities exist that can be used to gather this information. Examples include Arp, ipconfig/ifconfig, nbtstat, and route.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may look for details about the network configuration and settings, such as IP and/or MAC addresses, of systems they access or through information discovery of remote systems. Several operating system administration utilities exist that can be used to gather this information. Examples include Arp, ipconfig/ifconfig, nbtstat, and route.
Adversaries may also leverage a Network Device CLI on network devices to gather information about configurations and settings, such as IP addresses of configured interfaces and static/dynamic routes (e.g. show ip route, show ip interface).
Adversaries may use the information from System Network Configuration Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including determining certain access within the target network and what actions to do next.

sub_techniques.name: Internet Connection Discovery
sub_techniques.description: Adversaries may check for Internet connectivity on compromised systems. This may be performed during automated discovery and can be accomplished in numerous ways such as using Ping, tracert, and GET requests to websites.
sub_techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may check for Internet connectivity on compromised systems. This may be performed during automated discovery and can be accomplished in numerous ways such as using Ping, tracert, and GET requests to websites.
Adversaries may use the results and responses from these requests to determine if the system is capable of communicating with their C2 servers before attempting to connect to them. The results may also be used to identify routes, redirectors, and proxy servers.

sub_techniques.name: Wi-Fi Discovery
sub_techniques.description: Adversaries may search for information about Wi-Fi networks, such as network names and passwords, on compromised systems. Adversaries may use Wi-Fi information as part of Account Discovery, Remote System Discovery, and other discovery or Credential Access activity to support both ongoing and future campaigns.
sub_techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may search for information about Wi-Fi networks, such as network names and passwords, on compromised systems. Adversaries may use Wi-Fi information as part of Account Discovery, Remote System Discovery, and other discovery or Credential Access activity to support both ongoing and future campaigns.
Adversaries may collect various types of information about Wi-Fi networks from hosts. For example, on Windows names and passwords of all Wi-Fi networks a device has previously connected to may be available through netsh wlan show profiles to enumerate Wi-Fi names and then netsh wlan show profile "Wi-Fi name" key=clear to show a Wi-Fi network’s corresponding password. Additionally, names and other details of locally reachable Wi-Fi networks can be discovered using calls to wlanAPI.dll Native API functions.
On Linux, names and passwords of all Wi-Fi-networks a device has previously connected to may be available in files under /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/. On macOS, the password of a known Wi-Fi may be identified with security find-generic-password -wa wifiname (requires admin username/password).

examples.name: Emotet

techniques.name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of network connections to or from the compromised system they are currently accessing or from remote systems by querying for information over the network.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of network connections to or from the compromised system they are currently accessing or from remote systems by querying for information over the network.
An adversary who gains access to a system that is part of a cloud-based environment may map out Virtual Private Clouds or Virtual Networks in order to determine what systems and services are connected. The actions performed are likely the same types of discovery techniques depending on the operating system, but the resulting information may include details about the networked cloud environment relevant to the adversary's goals. Cloud providers may have different ways in which their virtual networks operate. Similarly, adversaries who gain access to network devices may also perform similar discovery activities to gather information about connected systems and services.
Utilities and commands that acquire this information include netstat, "net use," and "net session" with Net. In Mac and Linux, netstat and lsof can be used to list current connections. who -a and w can be used to show which users are currently logged in, similar to "net session". Additionally, built-in features native to network devices and Network Device CLI may be used (e.g. show ip sockets, show tcp brief).

techniques.name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to identify the primary user, currently logged in user, set of users that commonly uses a system, or whether a user is actively using the system. They may do this, for example, by retrieving account usernames or by using OS Credential Dumping. The information may be collected in a number of different ways using other Discovery techniques, because user and username details are prevalent throughout a system and include running process ownership, file/directory ownership, session information, and system logs. Adversaries may use the information from System Owner/User Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may attempt to identify the primary user, currently logged in user, set of users that commonly uses a system, or whether a user is actively using the system. They may do this, for example, by retrieving account usernames or by using OS Credential Dumping. The information may be collected in a number of different ways using other Discovery techniques, because user and username details are prevalent throughout a system and include running process ownership, file/directory ownership, session information, and system logs. Adversaries may use the information from System Owner/User Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.
Various utilities and commands may acquire this information, including whoami. In macOS and Linux, the currently logged in user can be identified with w and who. On macOS the dscl . list /Users | grep -v '_' command can also be used to enumerate user accounts. Environment variables, such as %USERNAME% and $USER, may also be used to access this information.
On network devices, Network Device CLI commands such as show users and show ssh can be used to display users currently logged into the device.

techniques.name: System Service Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may try to gather information about registered local system services. Adversaries may obtain information about services using tools as well as OS utility commands such as sc query, tasklist /svc, systemctl --type=service, and net start.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may try to gather information about registered local system services. Adversaries may obtain information about services using tools as well as OS utility commands such as sc query, tasklist /svc, systemctl --type=service, and net start.
Adversaries may use the information from System Service Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.

techniques.name: System Time Discovery
techniques.description: An adversary may gather the system time and/or time zone from a local or remote system. The system time is set and stored by the Windows Time Service within a domain to maintain time synchronization between systems and services in an enterprise network.
techniques.detailed_description:
An adversary may gather the system time and/or time zone from a local or remote system. The system time is set and stored by the Windows Time Service within a domain to maintain time synchronization between systems and services in an enterprise network. 
System time information may be gathered in a number of ways, such as with Net on Windows by performing net time \hostname to gather the system time on a remote system. The victim's time zone may also be inferred from the current system time or gathered by using w32tm /tz.
On network devices, Network Device CLI commands such as show clock detail can be used to see the current time configuration.
This information could be useful for performing other techniques, such as executing a file with a Scheduled Task/Job, or to discover locality information based on time zone to assist in victim targeting (i.e. System Location Discovery). Adversaries may also use knowledge of system time as part of a time bomb, or delaying execution until a specified date/time.

techniques.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
techniques.description: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.
Adversaries may use several methods to accomplish Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion such as checking for security monitoring tools (e.g., Sysinternals, Wireshark, etc.) or other system artifacts associated with analysis or virtualization. Adversaries may also check for legitimate user activity to help determine if it is in an analysis environment. Additional methods include use of sleep timers or loops within malware code to avoid operating within a temporary sandbox.

sub_techniques.name: System Checks
sub_techniques.description: Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.
sub_techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.
Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary, but may involve behaviors such as Windows Management Instrumentation, PowerShell, System Information Discovery, and Query Registry to obtain system information and search for VME artifacts. Adversaries may search for VME artifacts in memory, processes, file system, hardware, and/or the Registry. Adversaries may use scripting to automate these checks  into one script and then have the program exit if it determines the system to be a virtual environment.
Checks could include generic system properties such as host/domain name and samples of network traffic. Adversaries may also check the network adapters addresses, CPU core count, and available memory/drive size.
Other common checks may enumerate services running that are unique to these applications, installed programs on the system, manufacturer/product fields for strings relating to virtual machine applications, and VME-specific hardware/processor instructions. In applications like VMWare, adversaries can also use a special I/O port to send commands and receive output.
Hardware checks, such as the presence of the fan, temperature, and audio devices, could also be used to gather evidence that can be indicative a virtual environment. Adversaries may also query for specific readings from these devices.

examples.name: Astaroth
examples.description: Astaroth can check for Windows product ID's used by sandboxes and usernames and disk serial numbers associated with analyst environments.

examples.name: AsyncRAT

examples.name: Operation Dream Job
examples.description: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used tools that conducted a variety of system checks to detect sandboxes or VMware services.

examples.name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
examples.description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D checks a number of system parameters to see if it is being run on real hardware or in a virtual machine environment, such as sysctl hw.model and the kernel boot time.

examples.name: P8RAT
examples.description: P8RAT can check the compromised host for processes associated with VMware or VirtualBox environments.

examples.name: PlugX
examples.description: PlugX checks if VMware tools is running in the background by searching for any process named "vmtoolsd".

examples.name: PoetRAT
examples.description: PoetRAT checked the size of the hard drive to determine if it was being run in a sandbox environment. In the event of sandbox detection, it would delete itself by overwriting the malware scripts with the contents of "License.txt" and exiting.

examples.name: Pupy
examples.description: Pupy has a module that checks a number of indicators on the system to determine if its running on a virtual machine.

examples.name: QakBot
examples.description: QakBot can check the compromised host for the presence of multiple executables associated with analysis tools and halt execution if any are found.

examples.name: Remcos
examples.description: Remcos searches for Sandboxie and VMware on the system.

examples.name: RogueRobin
examples.description: RogueRobin uses WMI to check BIOS version for VBOX, bochs, qemu, virtualbox, and vm to check for evidence that the script might be executing within an analysis environment.

examples.name: ROKRAT
examples.description: ROKRAT can check for VMware-related files and DLLs related to sandboxes.

examples.name: Saint Bot
examples.description: Saint Bot has run several virtual machine and sandbox checks, including checking if Sbiedll.dll is present in a list of loaded modules, comparing the machine name to HAL9TH and the user name to JohnDoe, and checking the BIOS version for known virtual machine identifiers.

examples.name: Shark
examples.description: Shark can stop execution if the screen width of the targeted machine is not over 600 pixels.

examples.name: Smoke Loader
examples.description: Smoke Loader scans processes to perform anti-VM checks.

examples.name: Snip3
examples.description: Snip3 has the ability to detect Windows Sandbox, VMWare, or VirtualBox by querying Win32_ComputerSystem to extract the Manufacturer string.

examples.name: SodaMaster
examples.description: SodaMaster can check for the presence of the Registry key HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\VMwareHostOpen.exe before proceeding to its main functionality.

examples.name: SUNBURST
examples.description: SUNBURST checked the domain name of the compromised host to verify it was running in a real environment.

examples.name: SVCReady
examples.description: SVCReady has the ability to determine if its runtime environment is virtualized.

examples.name: SynAck
examples.description: SynAck checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.

examples.name: Trojan.Karagany
examples.description: Trojan.Karagany can detect commonly used and generic virtualization platforms based primarily on drivers and file paths.

examples.name: UBoatRAT
examples.description: UBoatRAT checks for virtualization software such as VMWare, VirtualBox, or QEmu on the compromised machine.

examples.name: Volt Typhoon
examples.description: Volt Typhoon has run system checks to determine if they were operating in a virtualized environment.

examples.name: WastedLocker
examples.description: WastedLocker checked if UCOMIEnumConnections and IActiveScriptParseProcedure32 Registry keys were detected as part of its anti-analysis technique.

examples.name: WhisperGate
examples.description: WhisperGate can stop its execution when it recognizes the presence of certain monitoring tools.

examples.name: yty
examples.description: yty has some basic anti-sandbox detection that tries to detect Virtual PC, Sandboxie, and VMware.

sub_techniques.name: User Activity Based Checks
sub_techniques.description: Adversaries may employ various user activity checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.
sub_techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may employ various user activity checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.
Adversaries may search for user activity on the host based on variables such as the speed/frequency of mouse movements and clicks  , browser history, cache, bookmarks, or number of files in common directories such as home or the desktop. Other methods may rely on specific user interaction with the system before the malicious code is activated, such as waiting for a document to close before activating a macro  or waiting for a user to double click on an embedded image to activate.

examples.name: Darkhotel
examples.description: Darkhotel has used malware that repeatedly checks the mouse cursor position to determine if a real user is on the system.

examples.name: FIN7
examples.description: FIN7 used images embedded into document lures that only activate the payload when a user double clicks to avoid sandboxes.

examples.name: Okrum
examples.description: Okrum loader only executes the payload after the left mouse button has been pressed at least three times, in order to avoid being executed within virtualized or emulated environments.

examples.name: Spark
examples.description: Spark has used a splash screen to check whether an user actively clicks on the screen before running malicious code.

sub_techniques.name: Time Based Evasion
sub_techniques.description: Adversaries may employ various time-based methods to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include enumerating time-based properties, such as uptime or the system clock, as well as the use of timers or other triggers to avoid a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox, specifically those that are automated or only operate for a limited amount of time.
sub_techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may employ various time-based methods to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include enumerating time-based properties, such as uptime or the system clock, as well as the use of timers or other triggers to avoid a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox, specifically those that are automated or only operate for a limited amount of time.
Adversaries may employ various time-based evasions, such as delaying malware functionality upon initial execution using programmatic sleep commands or native system scheduling functionality (ex: Scheduled Task/Job). Delays may also be based on waiting for specific victim conditions to be met (ex: system time, events, etc.) or employ scheduled Multi-Stage Channels to avoid analysis and scrutiny.
Benign commands or other operations may also be used to delay malware execution. Loops or otherwise needless repetitions of commands, such as Pings, may be used to delay malware execution and potentially exceed time thresholds of automated analysis environments. Another variation, commonly referred to as API hammering, involves making various calls to Native API functions in order to delay execution (while also potentially overloading analysis environments with junk data).
Adversaries may also use time as a metric to detect sandboxes and analysis environments, particularly those that attempt to manipulate time mechanisms to simulate longer elapses of time. For example, an adversary may be able to identify a sandbox accelerating time by sampling and calculating the expected value for an environment's timestamp before and after execution of a sleep function.

examples.name: AppleJeus
examples.description: AppleJeus has waited a specified time before downloading a second stage payload.

examples.name: BADFLICK
examples.description: BADFLICK has delayed communication to the actor-controlled IP address by 5 minutes.

examples.name: Bazar
examples.description: Bazar can use a timer to delay execution of core functionality.

examples.name: BendyBear
examples.description: BendyBear can check for analysis environments and signs of debugging using the Windows API kernel32!GetTickCountKernel32 call.

examples.name: Bisonal
examples.description: Bisonal has checked if the malware is running in a virtual environment with the anti-debug function GetTickCount() to compare the timing.

examples.name: Brute Ratel C4
examples.description: Brute Ratel C4 can call NtDelayExecution to pause execution.

examples.name: Bumblebee
examples.description: Bumblebee has the ability to set a hardcoded and randomized sleep interval.

examples.name: Clambling
examples.description: Clambling can wait 30 minutes before initiating contact with C2.

examples.name: Clop
examples.description: Clop has used the sleep command to avoid sandbox detection.

examples.name: Crimson
examples.description: Crimson can determine when it has been installed on a host for at least 15 days before downloading the final payload.

examples.name: DarkTortilla
examples.description: DarkTortilla can implement the kernel32.dll Sleep function to delay execution for up to 300 seconds before implementing persistence or processing an addon package.

examples.name: DRATzarus
examples.description: DRATzarus can use the GetTickCount and GetSystemTimeAsFileTime API calls to measure function timing. DRATzarus can also remotely shut down into sleep mode under specific conditions to evade detection.

examples.name: Egregor
examples.description: Egregor can perform a  long sleep (greater than or equal to 3 minutes) to evade detection.

examples.name: EvilBunny
examples.description: EvilBunny has used time measurements from 3 different APIs before and after performing sleep operations to check and abort if the malware is running in a sandbox.

examples.name: FatDuke
examples.description: FatDuke can turn itself on or off at random intervals.

examples.name: GoldenSpy
examples.description: GoldenSpy's installer has delayed installation of GoldenSpy for two hours after it reaches a victim system.

examples.name: GoldMax
examples.description: GoldMax has set an execution trigger date and time, stored as an ASCII Unix/Epoch time value.

examples.name: GrimAgent
examples.description: GrimAgent can sleep for 195 - 205 seconds after payload execution and before deleting its task.

examples.name: GuLoader
examples.description: GuLoader has the ability to perform anti-debugging based on time checks, API calls, and CPUID.

examples.name: HermeticWiper
examples.description: HermeticWiper has the ability to receive a command parameter to sleep prior to carrying out destructive actions on a targeted host.

examples.name: LiteDuke
examples.description: LiteDuke can wait 30 seconds before executing additional code if security software is detected.

examples.name: Lokibot
examples.description: Lokibot has performed a time-based anti-debug check before downloading its third stage.

examples.name: metaMain
examples.description: metaMain has delayed execution for five to six minutes during its persistence establishment process.

examples.name: Okrum
examples.description: Okrum's loader can detect presence of an emulator by using two calls to GetTickCount API, and checking whether the time has been accelerated.

examples.name: Operation Dream Job
examples.description: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group used tools that collected GetTickCount and GetSystemTimeAsFileTime data to detect sandbox or VMware services.

examples.name: P8RAT
examples.description: P8RAT has the ability to "sleep" for a specified time to evade detection.

examples.name: Pony
examples.description: Pony has delayed execution using a built-in function to avoid detection and analysis.

examples.name: QakBot
examples.description: The QakBot dropper can delay dropping the payload to evade detection.

examples.name: Raindrop
examples.description: After initial installation, Raindrop runs a computation to delay execution.

examples.name: Saint Bot
examples.description: Saint Bot has used the command timeout 20 to pause the execution of its initial loader.

examples.name: Snip3
examples.description: Snip3 can execute WScript.Sleep to delay execution of its second stage.

examples.name: SodaMaster
examples.description: SodaMaster has the ability to put itself to "sleep" for a specified time.

examples.name: StrifeWater
examples.description: StrifeWater can modify its sleep time responses from the default of 20-22 seconds.

examples.name: SUNBURST
examples.description: SUNBURST remained dormant after initial access for a period of up to two weeks.

examples.name: SVCReady
examples.description: SVCReady can enter a sleep stage for 30 minutes to evade detection.

examples.name: ThiefQuest
examples.description: ThiefQuest invokes time call to check the system's time, executes a sleep command, invokes a second time call, and then compares the time difference between the two time calls and the amount of time the system slept to identify the sandbox.

examples.name: Tomiris
examples.description: Tomiris has the ability to sleep for at least nine minutes to evade sandbox-based analysis systems.

examples.name: TrickBot
examples.description: TrickBot has used printf and file I/O loops to delay process execution as part of API hammering.

examples.name: Ursnif
examples.description: Ursnif has used a 30 minute delay after execution to evade sandbox monitoring tools.

examples.name: WhisperGate
examples.description: WhisperGate can pause for 20 seconds to bypass antivirus solutions.

examples.name: XCSSET
examples.description: Using the machine's local time, XCSSET waits 43200 seconds (12 hours) from the initial creation timestamp of a specific file, .report. After the elapsed time, XCSSET executes additional modules.

tactics.name: Lateral Movement
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to move through your environment.Lateral Movement consists of techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network. Following through on their primary objective often requires exploring the network to find their target and subsequently gaining access to it. Reaching their objective often involves pivoting through multiple systems and accounts to gain. Adversaries might install their own remote access tools to accomplish Lateral Movement or use legitimate credentials with native network and operating system tools, which may be stealthier.

techniques.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
techniques.description: Adversaries may exploit remote services to gain unauthorized access to internal systems once inside of a network. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. A common goal for post-compromise exploitation of remote services is for lateral movement to enable access to a remote system.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may exploit remote services to gain unauthorized access to internal systems once inside of a network. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. A common goal for post-compromise exploitation of remote services is for lateral movement to enable access to a remote system.
An adversary may need to determine if the remote system is in a vulnerable state, which may be done through Network Service Discovery or other Discovery methods looking for common, vulnerable software that may be deployed in the network, the lack of certain patches that may indicate vulnerabilities,  or security software that may be used to detect or contain remote exploitation. Servers are likely a high value target for lateral movement exploitation, but endpoint systems may also be at risk if they provide an advantage or access to additional resources.
There are several well-known vulnerabilities that exist in common services such as SMB  and RDP  as well as applications that may be used within internal networks such as MySQL  and web server services.
Depending on the permissions level of the vulnerable remote service an adversary may achieve Exploitation for Privilege Escalation as a result of lateral movement exploitation as well.

examples.name: APT28
examples.description: APT28 exploited a Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability to conduct lateral movement.

examples.name: Bad Rabbit
examples.description: Bad Rabbit used the EternalRomance SMB exploit to spread through victim networks.

examples.name: Conficker
examples.description: Conficker exploited the MS08-067 Windows vulnerability for remote code execution through a crafted RPC request.

examples.name: Dragonfly
examples.description: Dragonfly has exploited a Windows Netlogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472) to obtain access to Windows Active Directory servers.

examples.name: Earth Lusca
examples.description: Earth Lusca has used Mimikatz to exploit a domain controller via the ZeroLogon exploit (CVE-2020-1472).

examples.name: Emotet
examples.description: Emotet has been seen exploiting SMB via a vulnerability exploit like EternalBlue (MS17-010) to achieve lateral movement and propagation.

examples.name: Empire
examples.description: Empire has a limited number of built-in modules for exploiting remote SMB, JBoss, and Jenkins servers.

examples.name: FIN7
examples.description: FIN7 has exploited ZeroLogon (CVE-2020-1472) against vulnerable domain controllers.

examples.name: Flame
examples.description: Flame can use MS10-061 to exploit a print spooler vulnerability in a remote system with a shared printer in order to move laterally.

examples.name: Fox Kitten
examples.description: Fox Kitten has exploited known vulnerabilities in remote services including RDP.

examples.name: InvisiMole
examples.description: InvisiMole can spread within a network via the BlueKeep (CVE-2019-0708) and EternalBlue (CVE-2017-0144) vulnerabilities in RDP and SMB respectively.

examples.name: Lucifer
examples.description: Lucifer can exploit multiple vulnerabilities including EternalBlue (CVE-2017-0144) and EternalRomance (CVE-2017-0144).

examples.name: menuPass
examples.description: menuPass has used tools to exploit the ZeroLogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472).

examples.name: MuddyWater
examples.description: MuddyWater has exploited the Microsoft Netlogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472).

examples.name: NotPetya
examples.description: NotPetya can use two exploits in SMBv1, EternalBlue and EternalRomance, to spread itself to other remote systems on the network.

examples.name: PoshC2
examples.description: PoshC2 contains a module for exploiting SMB via EternalBlue.

examples.name: QakBot
examples.description: QakBot can move laterally using worm-like functionality through exploitation of SMB.

examples.name: Stuxnet
examples.description: Stuxnet propagates using the MS10-061 Print Spooler and MS08-067 Windows Server Service vulnerabilities.

examples.name: Threat Group-3390
examples.description: Threat Group-3390 has exploited MS17-010 to move laterally to other systems on the network.

examples.name: Tonto Team
examples.description: Tonto Team has used EternalBlue exploits for lateral movement.

examples.name: TrickBot
examples.description: TrickBot utilizes EternalBlue and EternalRomance exploits for lateral movement in the modules wormwinDll, wormDll, mwormDll, nwormDll, tabDll.

examples.name: WannaCry
examples.description: WannaCry uses an exploit in SMBv1 to spread itself to other remote systems on a network.

examples.name: Wizard Spider
examples.description: Wizard Spider has exploited or attempted to exploit Zerologon (CVE-2020-1472) and EternalBlue (MS17-010) vulnerabilities.

techniques.name: Internal Spearphishing
techniques.description: Adversaries may use internal spearphishing to gain access to additional information or exploit other users within the same organization after they already have access to accounts or systems within the environment. Internal spearphishing is multi-staged campaign where an email account is owned either by controlling the user's device with previously installed malware or by compromising the account credentials of the user. Adversaries attempt to take advantage of a trusted internal account to increase the likelihood of tricking the target into falling for the phish attempt.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may use internal spearphishing to gain access to additional information or exploit other users within the same organization after they already have access to accounts or systems within the environment. Internal spearphishing is multi-staged campaign where an email account is owned either by controlling the user's device with previously installed malware or by compromising the account credentials of the user. Adversaries attempt to take advantage of a trusted internal account to increase the likelihood of tricking the target into falling for the phish attempt.
Adversaries may leverage Spearphishing Attachment or Spearphishing Link as part of internal spearphishing to deliver a payload or redirect to an external site to capture credentials through Input Capture on sites that mimic email login interfaces.
There have been notable incidents where internal spearphishing has been used. The Eye Pyramid campaign used phishing emails with malicious attachments for lateral movement between victims, compromising nearly 18,000 email accounts in the process. The Syrian Electronic Army (SEA) compromised email accounts at the Financial Times (FT) to steal additional account credentials. Once FT learned of the campaign and began warning employees of the threat, the SEA sent phishing emails mimicking the Financial Times IT department and were able to compromise even more users.

examples.name: Gamaredon Group
examples.description: Gamaredon Group has used an Outlook VBA module on infected systems to send phishing emails with malicious attachments to other employees within the organization.

examples.name: HEXANE
examples.description: HEXANE has conducted internal spearphishing attacks against executives, HR, and IT personnel to gain information and access.

examples.name: Kimsuky
examples.description: Kimsuky has sent internal spearphishing emails for lateral movement after stealing victim information.

examples.name: Leviathan
examples.description: Leviathan has conducted internal spearphishing within the victim's environment for lateral movement.

examples.name: Operation Dream Job
examples.description: During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group conducted internal spearphishing from within a compromised organization.

techniques.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
techniques.description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files between systems in a compromised environment. Once brought into the victim environment (i.e., Ingress Tool Transfer) files may then be copied from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation.
techniques.detailed_description:
Adversaries may transfer tools or other files between systems in a compromised environment. Once brought into the victim environment (i.e., Ingress Tool Transfer) files may then be copied from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation.
Adversaries may copy files between internal victim systems to support lateral movement using inherent file sharing protocols such as file sharing over SMB/Windows Admin Shares to connected network shares or with authenticated connections via Remote Desktop Protocol.
Files can also be transferred using native or otherwise present tools on the victim system, such as scp, rsync, curl, sftp, and ftp. In some cases, adversaries may be able to leverage Web Services such as Dropbox or OneDrive to copy files from one machine to another via shared, automatically synced folders.

examples.name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
examples.description: During the 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack, Sandworm Team moved their tools laterally within the corporate network and between the ICS and corporate network.

examples.name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
examples.description: During the 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack, Sandworm Team used move to transfer files to a network share.

examples.name: Aoqin Dragon
examples.description: Aoqin Dragon has spread malware in target networks by copying modules to folders masquerading as removable devices.

examples.name: APT32
examples.description: APT32 has deployed tools after moving laterally using administrative accounts.

examples.name: BITSAdmin
examples.description: BITSAdmin can be used to create BITS Jobs to upload and/or download files from SMB file servers.

examples.name: BlackCat

examples.name: C0015

examples.name: C0018
examples.description: During C0018, the threat actors transferred the SoftPerfect Network Scanner and other tools to machines in the network using AnyDesk and PDQ Deploy.

examples.name: Chimera
examples.description: Chimera has copied tools between compromised hosts using SMB.

examples.name: cmd
examples.description: cmd can be used to copy files to/from a remotely connected internal system.

examples.name: DustySky
examples.description: DustySky searches for network drives and removable media and duplicates itself onto them.

examples.name: Emotet

examples.name: esentutl
examples.description: esentutl can be used to copy files to/from a remote share.

examples.name: Expand
examples.description: Expand can be used to download or upload a file over a network share.

examples.name: FIN10
examples.description: FIN10 has deployed Meterpreter stagers and SplinterRAT instances in the victim network after moving laterally.

examples.name: ftp
examples.description: ftp may be abused by adversaries to transfer tools or files between systems within a compromised environment.

examples.name: GALLIUM

examples.name: HermeticWizard

examples.name: LockerGoga

examples.name: Lucifer

examples.name: Magic Hound

examples.description: During Operation Wocao, threat actors used SMB to copy files to and from target systems.

examples.name: PsExec

examples.name: Sandworm Team
examples.description: Sandworm Team has used move to transfer files to a network share and has copied payloads--such as Prestige ransomware--to an Active Directory Domain Controller and distributed via the Default Domain Group Policy Object.

examples.name: Shamoon
examples.description: Shamoon attempts to copy itself to remote machines on the network.

examples.name: Stuxnet
examples.description: Stuxnet uses an RPC server that contains a file dropping routine and support for payload version updates for P2P communications within a victim network.

examples.name: Turla

examples.name: Volt Typhoon
examples.description: Volt Typhoon has copied web shells between servers in targeted environments.

examples.name: WannaCry
